messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 51 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Distributed Construction of Lightweight Spanners for Unit Ball Graphs

Paper Abstract: Abstract Resolving an open question from 2006 [15], we prove the existence of light-weight bounded-degree spanners for unit ball graphs in the metrics of bounded doubling dimension, and we design a simple ùí™‚Äã(log‚àó‚Å°n)ùí™superscriptùëõ\mathcal{O}(\log^{*}n)-round distributed algorithm in the LOCAL model of computation, that given a unit ball graph Gùê∫G with nùëõn vertices and a positive constant œµ<1italic-œµ1\epsilon<1 finds a (1+œµ)1italic-œµ(1+\epsilon)-spanner with constant bounds on its maximum degree and its lightness using only 2-hop neighborhood information. This immediately improves the best prior lightness bound, the algorithm of Damian, Pandit, and Pemmaraju [14], which runs in ùí™‚Äã(log‚àó‚Å°n)ùí™superscriptùëõ\mathcal{O}(\log^{*}n) rounds in the LOCAL model, but has a ùí™‚Äã(log‚Å°Œî)ùí™Œî\mathcal{O}(\log\Delta) bound on its lightness, where ŒîŒî\Delta is the ratio of the length of the longest edge to the length of the shortest edge in the unit ball graph. Next, we adjust our algorithm to work in the CONGEST model, without changing its round complexity, hence proposing the first spanner construction for unit ball graphs in the CONGEST model of computation. We further study the problem in the two dimensional Euclidean plane and we provide a construction with similar properties that has a constant average number of edge intersections per node. Lastly, we provide experimental results that confirm our theoretical bounds, and show an efficient performance from our distributed algorithm compared to the best known centralized construction.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 51 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 51"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Region-fault tolerant geometric spanners",
        "Generating sparse spanners for weighted graphs",
        "Geometric spanners for wireless ad hoc networks",
        "Near-linear time construction of sparse neighborhood covers",
        "Additive spanners and (Œ±,Œ≤)-spanners",
        "Online spanners in metric spaces",
        "Greedy spanners are optimal in doubling metrics",
        "Opus: an overlay peer utility service",
        "Small hop-diameter sparse spanners for doubling metrics",
        "Approximate shortest paths and distance oracles in weighted unit-disk graphs",
        "Fault tolerant spanners for general graphs",
        "There are planar graphs almost as good as the complete graph",
        "Fast algorithms for constructing t-spanners and paths with stretch t",
        "Distributed spanner construction in doubling metric spaces",
        "Local approximation schemes for topology control",
        "The visibility graph contains a bounded-degree spanner",
        "Sparse roadmap spanners for asymptotically near-optimal motion planning",
        "Computing almost shortest paths",
        "Distributed construction of light networks",
        "(1+Œµ,Œ≤)-spanner constructions for general graphs",
        "Efficient algorithms for constructing (1+Œµ,Œ≤)-spanners in the distributed and streaming models",
        "Spanning trees and spanners",
        "Crossing patterns in nonplanar road networks",
        "On the edge crossings of the greedy spanner",
        "Experimental study of geometric t-spanners",
        "Graph distances in the streaming model: the value of space",
        "The greedy spanner is existentially optimal",
        "Geometric spanners for routing in mobile networks",
        "A light metric spanner",
        "Fast greedy algorithms for constructing sparse geometric spanners",
        "Local construction of spanners in the 3d space",
        "On local algorithms for topology control and routing in ad hoc networks",
        "Computing lightweight spanners locally",
        "Approximating the complete Euclidean graph",
        "On the locality of bounded growth",
        "Truly optimal Euclidean spanners",
        "Greedy spanners in euclidean spaces admit sublinear separators",
        "Design and analysis of an mst-based topology control algorithm",
        "Localized delaunay triangulation with application in ad hoc wireless networks",
        "Power efficient and sparse spanner for wireless ad hoc networks",
        "Asymptotically near-optimal planning with probabilistic roadmap spanners",
        "Compact routing in unit disk graphs",
        "Geometric spanner networks",
        "Localized spanner construction for ad hoc networks with variable transmission range",
        "Graph spanners",
        "On dynamic shortest paths problems",
        "A log-star distributed maximal independent set algorithm for growth-bounded graphs",
        "The weak gap property in metric spaces of bounded doubling dimension",
        "Network overlay construction under limited end-to-end reachability",
        "Topology control for minimizing interference with delay constraints in an ad hoc network",
        "Distributed spanner construction with physical interference: constant stretch and linear sparseness"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 51 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Distributed Construction of Lightweight Spanners for Unit Ball Graphs, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
